Description: Fragment of a seal-impression made of fine brown Nile clay that was hardened after excavation and shows darker discolouration and a very glossy surface. It also shows blackened parts probably from fire. The rear shows a slightly concave area with the impression of wood, probably from a bolt or a box knob, perpendicular to this an impression of a turned cord with a width of approximately 0.20 cm. The front side is slightly convex with finger impressions and shows part of an oval seal. The motif shows a standing falcon-bird, facing to the left with a flagellum behind his body. In front of the falcon another sign, probably walking legs (D54).
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Amara West (Nubia), E14.7 temple magazine
Acquisition notes: Formerly housed by the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery and the EES London.
